<ce:figure id="fig7">
<ce:label>Scheme 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all"> </ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr7"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Showing the coordination environments of Zn(II) and μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> bridging modes of ligands (represented by green quadrangle for the μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>, and cyan and magenta pentagons for the μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>). Symmetry codes: (A) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2; (B) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2; (C) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2; (D) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2; (E) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1; (F) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2; G −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Showing the coordination environments of Zn(II) and μ4-HL and μ5-L bridging modes of ligands (represented by green quadrangle for the μ4-HL, and cyan and magenta pentagons for the μ5-L). Symmetry codes: (A) -x, -y +1, -z +2; (B) -x +1/2, -y +1, z +1/2; (C) x +1/2, y, -z +1/2; (D) -x +1/2, -y +1, z + -1/2; (E) -x +1, -y +1, -z +1; (F) -x, y +1/2, -z +3/2; G -x, y +1/2, -z +1. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View of (a) the four-fold helical structure along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis and (b) one-dimensional open channel presenting the guest-coordination sites at channel walls. The DMF molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View of (a) the four-fold helical structure along the a-axis and (b) one-dimensional open channel presenting the guest-coordination sites at channel walls. The DMF molecules and hydrogen atoms are omitted in 1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Views of (a) the microporous network omitting the DMF molecules, (b) the 3D (4,6)-connected network of (3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(3.4<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> topology of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with Zn(1), Zn(2) and Zn(3) as nodes (Zn(1), turquoise; Zn(2), indigo and Zn(3), pink). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Views of (a) the microporous network omitting the DMF molecules, (b) the 3D (4,6)-connected network of (32.52.62)(3.45.57.62)2 topology of 1 with Zn(1), Zn(2) and Zn(3) as nodes (Zn(1), turquoise; Zn(2), indigo and Zn(3), pink). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel 3D metal-organic framework of zinc(II) imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate, [Zn5(L)2(HL)2(DMF)4] n  (1) (H3 L =4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid), was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. This compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with the space group Pbca and cell parameters a =14.1613(8)Å, b =15.6764(9)Å, c =16.1345(9), V =3581.8(4)Å3 and Z =4. The crystal structure presents a novel 3D framework with the rare four-fold helical structure and open channels, exhibiting guest-coordination sites at channel walls and strong fluorescent emission.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In recent years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable attention as promising materials for many applications, such as catalysis, separation, gas storage, sensor, magnetism, fluorescence, ion exchange and so on . Especially, microporous metal-organic frameworks (MMOFs) incorporating coordinatively unsaturated metal ions at cavity or channel walls are of great interest due to their highly selective incorporation for guests as well as hydrogen bonding sites . Furthermore, they can also provide functionalities as flexible frameworks because ligation and release of the guests often influence the coordination geometry or splitting of the d-orbitals . However, the syntheses of such compounds are still very difficult because metal ions tend to occur in nodes of frameworks and therefore all the coordination sites are occupied by bridging ligands and/or counter anions. In this regard, the MMOFs with coordination sites that contain volatile neutral molecules, such as water, alcohols, acetonitrile, and DMF have the capacity to create coordinatively unsaturated metal ions within their pores after removal of any volatile molecules by heating and/or vacuum, without inducing any decomposition of their original porous frameworks . On the other hand, such complexes involving d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal ions (Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>) exhibit excellent fluorescent emissions in the solid state . Herein, we employed a rigid imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) ligand  to react with Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in DMF to obtain a novel three-dimensional MMOF, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The title compound exhibits a four-fold helical structure and open channels with guest-coordination sites at channel walls and strong fluorescent emission.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable attention as promising materials for many applications, such as catalysis, separation, gas storage, sensor, magnetism, fluorescence, ion exchange and so on . Especially, microporous metal-organic frameworks (MMOFs) incorporating coordinatively unsaturated metal ions at cavity or channel walls are of great interest due to their highly selective incorporation for guests as well as hydrogen bonding sites . Furthermore, they can also provide functionalities as flexible frameworks because ligation and release of the guests often influence the coordination geometry or splitting of the d-orbitals . However, the syntheses of such compounds are still very difficult because metal ions tend to occur in nodes of frameworks and therefore all the coordination sites are occupied by bridging ligands and/or counter anions. In this regard, the MMOFs with coordination sites that contain volatile neutral molecules, such as water, alcohols, acetonitrile, and DMF have the capacity to create coordinatively unsaturated metal ions within their pores after removal of any volatile molecules by heating and/or vacuum, without inducing any decomposition of their original porous frameworks . On the other hand, such complexes involving d10 metal ions (ZnII or CdII) exhibit excellent fluorescent emissions in the solid state . Herein, we employed a rigid imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3 L) ligand  to react with Zn(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O in DMF to obtain a novel three-dimensional MMOF, [Zn5(L)2(HL)2(DMF)4] n  (1). The title compound exhibits a four-fold helical structure and open channels with guest-coordination sites at channel walls and strong fluorescent emission.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and general methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All the solvents and reagents for synthesis including imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.) were commercially available, analytical grade, and used as received. All characterizations were carried out using a fresh sample. The FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in range of 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a JASCO FT/IR-230 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer. The thermal stability (TG) studies were carried out using a Shimadzu DTG-50 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under a He flow at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The fluorescent emission spectrum was taken using a Perkin–Elmer LS50B Luminescence Spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were carried out on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 Analyzer. BET surface area was taken using automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (ASAP2010, Micromeritics).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

All the solvents and reagents for synthesis including imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.) were commercially available, analytical grade, and used as received. All characterizations were carried out using a fresh sample. The FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded in range of 400-4000cm-1 on a JASCO FT/IR-230 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer. The thermal stability (TG) studies were carried out using a Shimadzu DTG-50 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 600°C with a heating rate of 5°Cmin-1 under a He flow at 150mLmin-1. The fluorescent emission spectrum was taken using a Perkin-Elmer LS50B Luminescence Spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were carried out on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Analyzer. BET surface area was taken using automatic volumetric adsorption equipment (ASAP2010, Micromeritics).

<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) (312<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) inside a Teflon-capped scintillation vial at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C afforded the colorless crystals from the bottom of the vial after 4 days. The crystals were successively rinsed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, EtOH and Et<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air. Yield: 31% (based on Zn). IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3418s, 2397m, 1662vs, 1533vs, 1387s, 1303m, 1239m, 1101m, 843w, 670m. Anal. Calcd for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: C, 28.72; H, 1.85; N, 12.88. Found: C, 28.14; H, 1.36; N, 13.38.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and general characterization

Treatment of a 10mL DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (595mg, 2mmol) and imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3 L) (312mg, 2mmol) inside a Teflon-capped scintillation vial at 140°C afforded the colorless crystals from the bottom of the vial after 4 days. The crystals were successively rinsed with H2O, EtOH and Et2O and dried in air. Yield: 31% (based on Zn). IR (KBr, cm-1): υ =3418s, 2397m, 1662vs, 1533vs, 1387s, 1303m, 1239m, 1101m, 843w, 670m. Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 28.72; H, 1.85; N, 12.88. Found: C, 28.14; H, 1.36; N, 13.38.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystallographic data collection and structure</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was performed using a BRUKER SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection. The intensity data were collected using Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in the <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> scan mode in the range of 2.22°<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>28.22° at 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The unit cell parameters and integrations of the diffraction profiles were determined using SAINT program . All data were corrected by a semi-empirical method using the SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXL-97 package and refined with SHELXL . The Zn(II) atom was located from the E-map and other non-hydrogen atoms were discovered through subsequent and successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. All hydrogen atoms were placed in the geometrically calculated positions. The refinement converged to the final <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data collection and structure

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of 1 was performed using a BRUKER SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection. The intensity data were collected using Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) in the ω scan mode in the range of 2.22°< θ <28.22° at 20°C. The unit cell parameters and integrations of the diffraction profiles were determined using SAINT program . All data were corrected by a semi-empirical method using the SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXL-97 package and refined with SHELXL . The Zn(II) atom was located from the E-map and other non-hydrogen atoms were discovered through subsequent and successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for all the non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. All hydrogen atoms were placed in the geometrically calculated positions. The refinement converged to the final R 1 =0.0442, wR 1 =0.1272, and S =1.059. The molecular graphics were drawn using Diamond 3.0d. Further crystallographic data and experimental details for the structural analyses of 1 are summarized in  , and the selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations in   (No. CCDC 600422).

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of structure

Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca and consists of the tri-deprotonated L and bis-deprotonated HL ligands coordinating to Zn(II) ions ( ).   shows the partial molecular structure of 1 with μ4- and μ5-bridging mode ligands (represented by green quadrangle for the μ4-HL, and cyan and magenta pentagons for the μ5-L). In this crystal, there are three crystallographically independent Zn(II) atoms. The Zn(1) atom adopts a six-coordinated environment by coordinating to two chelating NCCO's and two μ2-O atoms from two HL and two L ligands, respectively. The Zn(2) atom adopts a five-coordinated environment by coordinating to a chelating NCCO, an imidazolyl N atom and two μ2-O atoms from two HL and two L ligands, respectively, while the Zn(3) atom is based on an octahedral environment with four carboxyl O atoms from two different L ligands in the equatorial plane, and the two O atoms of DMF molecules at axial positions, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands bridge Zn(1) and Zn(2) ions to provide an undulated one-dimensional chain structure, which is bridged by Zn(3) ions to form a three-sheet layer. The distance of two adjacent Zn(1) and Zn(2) ions bridged by two μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O atoms is 3.849<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with the O–Zn–O bond angles of 67.0° and 68.4°, respectively. Furthermore, the adjacent two-dimensional sheet layers are bridged by μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands to form a three-dimensional network with open channels.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The μ5-L ligands bridge Zn(1) and Zn(2) ions to provide an undulated one-dimensional chain structure, which is bridged by Zn(3) ions to form a three-sheet layer. The distance of two adjacent Zn(1) and Zn(2) ions bridged by two μ2-O atoms is 3.849Å with the O-Zn-O bond angles of 67.0° and 68.4°, respectively. Furthermore, the adjacent two-dimensional sheet layers are bridged by μ4-HL ligands to form a three-dimensional network with open channels.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is worth noting that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> self-assembles into one-dimensional open channels along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a, when Zn(1), Zn(2) atoms, μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>-<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands act as nodes (omitting DMF and Zn(3) atom), we can easily find a four-fold helical chain structure in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> which is enlaced each other along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis to form a open channel with the dimension of 7.84<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. Omitting the neutral DMF molecules, Zn(3) ions inlay at channel walls through coordinating to four separate carboxyl O atoms from two <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands, which shows the significant guest-coordinated sites at channel walls (b). From the perspective of network topology, Zn(1), Zn(2) and Zn(3) atoms act as three nodes and ligands as bridges; Zn(3) represents a 4-connected node to connect two kinds of 6-connected Zn(II) ions (Zn(1), Zn(2)) nodes, resulting in a unique 3D (4,6)-connected net (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>) with Schläfli symbol of (3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) (3.4<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. So far, a variety of uninodal networks have been reported . However, higher-dimensional nets with mixed connectivity such as (3,6)-, (4,6)-, and (4,8)-connected frameworks are quite rare .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that complex 1 self-assembles into one-dimensional open channels along a-axis. As shown in  a, when Zn(1), Zn(2) atoms, μ4-HL and μ5-L ligands act as nodes (omitting DMF and Zn(3) atom), we can easily find a four-fold helical chain structure in 1 which is enlaced each other along a-axis to form a open channel with the dimension of 7.84×8.12Å2. Omitting the neutral DMF molecules, Zn(3) ions inlay at channel walls through coordinating to four separate carboxyl O atoms from two L ligands, which shows the significant guest-coordinated sites at channel walls (b). From the perspective of network topology, Zn(1), Zn(2) and Zn(3) atoms act as three nodes and ligands as bridges; Zn(3) represents a 4-connected node to connect two kinds of 6-connected Zn(II) ions (Zn(1), Zn(2)) nodes, resulting in a unique 3D (4,6)-connected net ( ) with Schläfli symbol of (32.52.62) (3.45.57.62)2 . So far, a variety of uninodal networks have been reported . However, higher-dimensional nets with mixed connectivity such as (3,6)-, (4,6)-, and (4,8)-connected frameworks are quite rare .

<ce:section-title>Thermal properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is an important aspect for metal-organic frameworks. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, the first weight loss of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> starts at 60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and does not end until 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is mainly attributed to the strong interactions of DMF with metal ions. The consecutive weight loss from 330 to 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is probably caused by the decomposition of ligand, resulting in the collapse of host framework. For confirming that the host framework remains intact accompanying with the loss of DMF molecules, the PXRD measurements were performed, which indicate that the solid after removal of DMF by heating <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C retains the initial framework which is consistent with the simulated one (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties of 1 

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stability of 1, which is an important aspect for metal-organic frameworks. As shown in  , the first weight loss of 1 starts at 60°C and does not end until 330°C, which is mainly attributed to the strong interactions of DMF with metal ions. The consecutive weight loss from 330 to 600°C is probably caused by the decomposition of ligand, resulting in the collapse of host framework. For confirming that the host framework remains intact accompanying with the loss of DMF molecules, the PXRD measurements were performed, which indicate that the solid after removal of DMF by heating 1 to 330°C retains the initial framework which is consistent with the simulated one ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Exchange of guest molecules of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Due to the strong interaction of DMF with metal ions, which makes it difficult to remove DMF from the open channels, a primary experiment immersing <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN solution for 3 days has been done to investigate whether DMF can be exchanged by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN . The IR spectra exhibit that the strong C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching bands of DMF in 1662<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> disappear after immersing in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN [IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3449m, 2398s, 1574vs, 1469s, 1388s, 1242m, 1097s, 1016m, 814w, 660m], implying that DMF have been exchanged by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN. The compound after guest exchange shows high crystallinity as indicated by sharp peaks observed in the PXRD pattern (). This observation shows that the cavity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is so flexible that CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules may be incorporated instead of DMF molecules without collapse or decomposition. From TG curve of the DMF-CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN exchanged product <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold>, it can be clearly seen that <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> completely loses guest molecules below 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and the decomposition of ligand accompanying with the collapse of host framework occurs between 330 and 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. It should be noted that <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> shows a two-step desolventized process, in which the first one may be attributed to the loss of uncoordinated guest molecules included in the channels after guest exchange  and the second one is the loss of exchanged guest molecules coordinated to Zn atoms. Furthermore, the BET surface area measurement shows that the desolventized <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold> possesses a surface area of 56.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>/g, implying the permanent porosity of <ce:bold>1a</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Exchange of guest molecules of 1 

Due to the strong interaction of DMF with metal ions, which makes it difficult to remove DMF from the open channels, a primary experiment immersing 1 in CH3CN solution for 3 days has been done to investigate whether DMF can be exchanged by CH3CN . The IR spectra exhibit that the strong CO stretching bands of DMF in 1662cm-1 disappear after immersing in CH3CN [IR (KBr, cm-1): υ =3449m, 2398s, 1574vs, 1469s, 1388s, 1242m, 1097s, 1016m, 814w, 660m], implying that DMF have been exchanged by CH3CN. The compound after guest exchange shows high crystallinity as indicated by sharp peaks observed in the PXRD pattern (). This observation shows that the cavity of 1 is so flexible that CH3CN molecules may be incorporated instead of DMF molecules without collapse or decomposition. From TG curve of the DMF-CH3CN exchanged product 1a, it can be clearly seen that 1a completely loses guest molecules below 300°C and the decomposition of ligand accompanying with the collapse of host framework occurs between 330 and 600°C. It should be noted that 1a shows a two-step desolventized process, in which the first one may be attributed to the loss of uncoordinated guest molecules included in the channels after guest exchange  and the second one is the loss of exchanged guest molecules coordinated to Zn atoms. Furthermore, the BET surface area measurement shows that the desolventized 1a possesses a surface area of 56.3m2/g, implying the permanent porosity of 1a.

<ce:section-title>Emission property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The photoluminescence spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was measured in the solid state at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). Upon excitation at 310<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows stronger fluorescent emission than that of the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand at 420<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. This may be attributed to the deprotonation of the ligand and the rigidity of framework . The strong fluorescence emission of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> makes it the potentially useful photoactive material because it is thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Emission property of 1 

The photoluminescence spectrum of 1 was measured in the solid state at room temperature ( ). Upon excitation at 310nm, complex 1 shows stronger fluorescent emission than that of the free H3 L ligand at 420nm. This may be attributed to the deprotonation of the ligand and the rigidity of framework . The strong fluorescence emission of 1 makes it the potentially useful photoactive material because it is thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized a novel three-dimensional microporous metal-organic framework with four-fold helical structure and open channels, which exhibit significant guest-coordination sites at channel walls. The strong blue emission of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the solid state may be potentially applicable as a material for blue-light-emitting diode devices.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized a novel three-dimensional microporous metal-organic framework with four-fold helical structure and open channels, which exhibit significant guest-coordination sites at channel walls. The strong blue emission of 1 in the solid state may be potentially applicable as a material for blue-light-emitting diode devices.

Synthesis and general characterization

Treatment of a 10mL DMF solution of Zn(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (595mg, 2mmol) and imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3 L) (312mg, 2mmol) inside a Teflon-capped scintillation vial at 140°C afforded the colorless crystals from the bottom of the vial after 4 days. The crystals were successively rinsed with H2O, EtOH and Et2O and dried in air. Yield: 31% (based on Zn). IR (KBr, cm-1): υ =3418s, 2397m, 1662vs, 1533vs, 1387s, 1303m, 1239m, 1101m, 843w, 670m. Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 28.72; H, 1.85; N, 12.88. Found: C, 28.14; H, 1.36; N, 13.38.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel 3D metal-organic framework of zinc(II) imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate, [Zn5(L)2(HL)2(DMF)4] n  (1) (H3 L =4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid), was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. This compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with the space group Pbca and cell parameters a =14.1613(8)Å, b =15.6764(9)Å, c =16.1345(9), V =3581.8(4)Å3 and Z =4. The crystal structure presents a novel 3D framework with the rare four-fold helical structure and open channels, exhibiting guest-coordination sites at channel walls and strong fluorescent emission.

Thermal properties of 1 

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments were conducted to determine the thermal stability of 1, which is an important aspect for metal-organic frameworks. As shown in  , the first weight loss of 1 starts at 60°C and does not end until 330°C, which is mainly attributed to the strong interactions of DMF with metal ions. The consecutive weight loss from 330 to 600°C is probably caused by the decomposition of ligand, resulting in the collapse of host framework. For confirming that the host framework remains intact accompanying with the loss of DMF molecules, the PXRD measurements were performed, which indicate that the solid after removal of DMF by heating 1 to 330°C retains the initial framework which is consistent with the simulated one ( ).

Exchange of guest molecules of 1 

Due to the strong interaction of DMF with metal ions, which makes it difficult to remove DMF from the open channels, a primary experiment immersing 1 in CH3CN solution for 3 days has been done to investigate whether DMF can be exchanged by CH3CN . The IR spectra exhibit that the strong CO stretching bands of DMF in 1662cm-1 disappear after immersing in CH3CN [IR (KBr, cm-1): υ =3449m, 2398s, 1574vs, 1469s, 1388s, 1242m, 1097s, 1016m, 814w, 660m], implying that DMF have been exchanged by CH3CN. The compound after guest exchange shows high crystallinity as indicated by sharp peaks observed in the PXRD pattern (). This observation shows that the cavity of 1 is so flexible that CH3CN molecules may be incorporated instead of DMF molecules without collapse or decomposition. From TG curve of the DMF-CH3CN exchanged product 1a, it can be clearly seen that 1a completely loses guest molecules below 300°C and the decomposition of ligand accompanying with the collapse of host framework occurs between 330 and 600°C. It should be noted that 1a shows a two-step desolventized process, in which the first one may be attributed to the loss of uncoordinated guest molecules included in the channels after guest exchange  and the second one is the loss of exchanged guest molecules coordinated to Zn atoms. Furthermore, the BET surface area measurement shows that the desolventized 1a possesses a surface area of 56.3m2/g, implying the permanent porosity of 1a.

Emission property of 1 

The photoluminescence spectrum of 1 was measured in the solid state at room temperature ( ). Upon excitation at 310nm, complex 1 shows stronger fluorescent emission than that of the free H3 L ligand at 420nm. This may be attributed to the deprotonation of the ligand and the rigidity of framework . The strong fluorescence emission of 1 makes it the potentially useful photoactive material because it is thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and nonpolar solvents.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules
strong interactions of DMF with metal ions
loss of exchanged guest molecules coordinated to Zn atoms
